title: For Sale/Trade:  2x Steyr-Mannlicher M95 carbines, with 445 rounds of 8x56R ammo and 29 enbloc clips
postcontent:
Up for sale/trade are two Steyr-Mannlicher M95 carbines, along with ammo and clips.  The M95 was the service weapon used by the Austro-Hungarians during WW1, and most M95s were then sold to Bulgaria in the 1930s and used by the Bulgarian Army during WW2.  It uses a unique straight pull action, which I found is faster and smoother than a traditional bolt action.

The first carbine is an original M95 'Stutzen' carbine, produced in 1915 in Budapest, Hungary.  All numbers match.  It comes with the original stock, but it has a small crack behind the tang, which should be repairable.  It is currently residing in a second, mismatched stock for shooting purposes.  It includes an original Bulgarian sling.

The second carbine is a M95/30 carbine, produced in 1916 in Steyr, Austria. It was originally a M95 long rifle that was later modified to carbine length by the Bulgarian Army in the 1930s.  It retains the original long rifle rear sight.  All numbers match, including the stock (though the stock and receiver were renumbered to match by the Bulgarians).

Interestingly, the markings show that this Austrian-made M95 was not used by the Austro-Hungarian Imperial Army like most M95s. Instead, it was used by the Hungarian Honvédség, which was the Hungarian territorial army. Both Austria and Hungary had home defense armies, independent of the joint Imperial Army.

Both carbines are S-marked for 8x56R ammo.  Both were refurbished by the Bulgarians after WW2, and are in very good condition with no mechanical issues.  Both have very good but somewhat frosty bores with prominent rifling.


Also included in the package are 445 rounds of 8x56R FMJ ammo, 29 enbloc clips, and 10 once-fired brass cases:
130 rounds of Austrian Nazi-headstamped ammo on clips and in the original boxes
10 rounds of Austrian Nazi-headstamped ammo on clips (no boxes)
100 rounds of loose Austrian Nazi-headstamped ammo

title: For Sale:  D Guard 13" Fighting Knife from 1916 Pancho Villa Expedition
location: West Little Rock, Little Rock, Arkansas
postcontent:
This antique bowie with reference to Villa is from the 1916 Pershing expedition into Mexico after Pancho Villa. Full D knuckle-duster guard. Leather sheath. Measures 13 3/8" overall with a 8 3/4" blade. 

The grip scales are celluloid, which dates the knife to pre-1920 or earlier, the style is of other fighting knives of the WW1 period, and the blade is etched with a reference to Pancho Villa: "...mí no me asusta un león, mucho menos si es panzó" or "I'm not scared of a lion, much less if he's pot-bellied." Pancho Villa was known as the Lion of the North and also was made fun of as a chubby man with a potbelly.

The Pershing expedition created a business boom in Mexico and this was most likely a souvenir sold to one of the US troops.

The other side of the blade is engraved with a running lion. There are 2 or 3 small chips on both sides of the grips. The blade is tarnished with some light rusting as shown, but ought to clean up nicely. The leather sheath is still soft and in very good shape with no damage other than the stitching has come lose from the bottom 2" or so of the sheath.
